I hate to do this -- but here goes . . . . I was totally craving local food (aka Mom's cooking) and thought I'd get my fix at Aloha Kitchen.  I'm from Maui, so . . . there's nothing quite like Mom's, but I thought this might come close. 

Our group had the chicken katsu, teriyaki chicken and teri beef plates with the rice and mac salad.  I can't say any of the above was worth a repeat visit. 

The katsu - I make better katsu myself and with that being said, I think L&L's katsu is better and . . . that's still L&L, not Mom's.  This was very garlicy, small strips of thin chicken with more crunch than chicken.  The sauce was ok, not best ever, but ok. Honestly could not finish it, I threw 1/2 of it away and I never do that. It was THAT bad.  And for the record, I had the bubbly stomach (gas) effect all afternoon.  Gross.

I think I have a problem with their teriyaki sauce.  The chicken was average and teri beef was chewy.  Sauce was ok, but like a 2-star says . . . "Meh. I've experienced better".  

I was most disappointed with the hard, dry rice - it's not hard to cook rice!!  Even my 8 year old makes better rice - cmon now!!  And then came the mac salad which again, L&L does better.  It wasn't awful, but it wasn't great either.  And it certainly wasn't Mom's.  

Would I go back?  Nope.  It's close to my work and I'd love to say I would.  But nope.  Place was pretty crowded though and I've been told to "order breakfast next time", but I wasn't feeling breakfast at 12:00 Noon.

Delicious food love coming here but the other night my card did not go through and the new girl said it was declined so I ask the lady that's been working there since for ever to help her swipe the card again she said she can't control the machine so I had to pay $4 to use the ATM and took my money somewhere-else accordingly them I did not have a valid debit card. Bad customer service
I love the poke and Kalbi plate is the best ! Always good service ... Yummy yummy yummy

whenever we go to vegas, we always meet up here with our vegas friends. it's not the best hawaiian food EVER or is as well known as the hawaiian joint at the CAL, but it always fulfills the hankering my bf always has for their adobo fried rice. i usually just get the combo that comes with the chicken teri/beef teri, mac salad and spam musubi. they give you plenty of food and it's not that expensive.yum!
The food is so good and the staff are friendly. Definitely would return. The adobo fried rice and lumpia had great flavor. Enjoyed every bite and the portions are perfect.

Filipino food AND Hawaiian plate lunch?! me thinks yes!!!

The Adobo Fried Rice Omelet is super ono/super sarap. Adobo Fried Rice wrapped in an omelet...fyi it's pretty ginormous & big enough to share. Otherwise one can conquer it if they're super hungry. The different plate lunches are really yummy too. Chicken Katsu plate served up w/ rice & mac salad. 

Don't forget to order a spam musubi too & get a can of Hawaiian Sun to wash it all down!

Aloha Kitchen isn't too far off the strip so if you're looking for some local cheap eats, big portions & good food then this is definitely worth trying!

So yummy. I can't wait to come again. 
I came here for the first time on Dec 16th while we were in town celebrating my son's birthday.
I always see relatives of mine check in here on FB and it made me curious after seeing the yelp reviews and photos and menu. I brought my parents along with me and my son of course. 
After my first visit, it's probably now my favorite place to eat when I come out now. My parents said the same thing. They said they are probably only going to come and eat there now when they come to Vegas. I got the adobo omelette which was so amazing and so ridiculously huge, my mom got longanisa, my dad got hashbrowns and eggs, and for my son, who is insanely picky, i got the kids teriyaki plate, which he surprisingly ate and I finished of course. I ate off of everyone's plate and everything I had was so good. I would post photos but my phone is not allowing me to right now for some reason. All of that food we ordered for about 30 something dollars. Totally worth it. My mouth waters thinking about eating here again. I wish they had locations in LA or the valley!

Aloha kitchen is a staple I don't know why I've never reviewed. I've been coming here since I moved to the valley in 2011, but only to the one on Sahara.

The staff is friendly and always walking around to make sure the customers are doing well. 
If we come in the morning we get the topsilog (Filipino breakfast dish) with over medium eggs, loco moco which is a HI staple. Their saimin is always a good go to if you looking for something light but filling. Now they offer oxtail soup year round with 2 heaping scoops of rice its SOOOOOO ono. The combination plate is the way to go if your not sure on what you want to eat it has a little bit of everything you cant go wrong and it comes with mac salad.  
Defiantly try their adobo omelet you wont be disappointed their are a few restaurants in town that offer it on their menu but there's something about Aloha's that just does it better, my fam from SD always requests me to pick one up when they are in town, and if they drove themselves they take one to go its that good. 

word of advice:
If your coming during lunch OR your short on time do yourself a favor and call your order in a head of time.
Karaoke was a blast, drinks are not too bad, staff is super friendly and attentive... we were not very thrilled about the mix plate that we ordered.

I ordered my meal from here through UberEATS due to being stuck at work. Needless to say I was highly disappointed in the food quality. It seems that the cut of meat has changed to a low quality. The steak was these hard little cubes, the rice was over cooked, and my pork was slightly burnt. The portions of meat were very small. The only decent part of the meal was the macaroni salad. Definitely not reminiscent of my visits to other Aloha Kitchens. Don't think I'll order from this location again. Looks like I'll stick with L&L BBQ.

First time eating at Aloha Kitchen. Ordered the Local Combo. There was pork, chicken, spam musubi, scoop of rice and a macaroni and cheese salad. The sauce that was on top of the chicken and pork was a bit too sweet for my liking. The salad I didn't like the taste of it. But overall it was too bad for $7.99. Maybe something else is better on the menu.
Terrible customer service, the cash register name Princess has no customer service. Never going here again

this is an update, I've finally had the chance to try the food!

so as the yelpers have said, I did decide to try the adobo fried rice. It's very good! I had some good chunks of meat in there. My friends just had beef teriyaki and shared a piece with me- it's very delicious as well! My brother had loco moco and loved it! They bring your meal to you via table number. I liked having hip hop music play, it's a nice atmosphere. I really do want to make this place a favorite spot!

I've been to many Hawaiian restaurants in Vegas and I can honestly say Aloha Kitchen is my favorite. Aloha Kitchen is located in a small strip mall on the Westside of Las Vegas. It's easy to miss if you aren't carefully looking for it.

PRO: Good food and good people! I suggest Trying:  Oxtail soup, Adobo Fried Rice Omelet, Loco Moco, Macadamia Pancakes, or the Local Plate.  Those are my favorite dishes... Food are freshly made and cooked! 

CON: I came to Aloha Kitchen & Bar when it was super busy. Although the staff were trying there best to take orders and push out the food in a timely manner. I requested water and waited for about 30 minutes. I just got frustrated and purchase a cup for myself.

Always loved this restaurant.the staff knows us and are aleays nice and welcome us. The sauce for the chicken teriyaki plate is so yummy that we always order extra and completely drown our chicken.also the loco moco is to die for. We live in summerlin but make the long drive anyways cuz its worth it

Great food and service. Love that they are open late! They have large portions and great prices. The service is always on point and they also have karaoke bar area that is separate from the dining area.

The food is alright. I had the local plate. The chicken and beef were ok, but the spam had way too much rice (served as a "sandwich").  I would only come here if i was in the area, but wouldn't be my first choice.

I ordered mahi mahi plate, it's an omelet  with very little fish and all egg. Dry and tasteless. Ox tail was so ordinary. They don't even have fish sauce to make it taste better. Not going back to this place!

Aloha Kitchen and Bar is more like a three and a half stars. 

I ordered chicken curry and I thought the chicken curry was going to be like Indian or Thai style, but I was wrong.  It was Hawaiian style and I have never heard of Hawaiian chicken curry.  It was different and they do not add coconut milk.  The dish was large--two scoops of rice, a scoop of macaroni salad, and a large serving of chicken curry.  The large serving was worth eight dollars, but I did not finish it.  

The karaoke bar was cool and entertaining.  However, I must caution you the music is loud, but I guess that is to be expected.  You get use to the noise once you are inside for a couple of hours.  

There is a lot of karaoke music to choose from.  The binder is about four inches thick and the music ranges from Hawaiian, Tagalog, Spanish, rap, rock, country, pop, and r&b.  Basically, whatever song you choose, it might be in the binder.  The binder is alphabetized by song.  Vegas has a lot of hidden singers.  They are really talented.  They should try out for American Idol or America Has Talent.   In between songs, they play danceable music like line dancing (the Electric Slide) or hip-hop.   However, I must add sometimes the microphone does not work.  

I did not sing because I was shy, but I guess if I were drunk, I wouldn't mind singing a song.

If your looking for "Fast food" Hawaiian style, this is the IT place to go.

Food: 4/5 The food here is actually pretty good, so good I swear aloha kitchen was thee place that caused my freshmen 10 (gaining of 10 pounds once you become a freshmen in college) I love getting the short ribs dish or something simple like the Teriyaki bowl. I usually don't order burgers but I recently decided to be adventurous and tried a teriyaki burger which was delicious.  

Service: 3/5 The service here is pretty good but I think that just might be part of that laid back Hawaiian culture. The place is kind of a mess though, I decided to dine in and I noticed a couple of booths were covered with left over rice and drips of sauces from the previous customer that sat there. Also maybe Aloha kitchen should remodel a bit because some of their booths chairs are ripping. 

Price: 4/5 The price here is cheap & the food comes out fast in good portions so your getting your moneys worth. 

Karaoke Bar: 0/5 I've never been in the karaoke bar but every time I dine in the walls must be thin or something but you can definitely hear some annoying chick on the other side screaming her lungs out. Very annoying while your trying to eat.
spark a blunt, order the adobo fried rice omelette, enjoy. call ahead.
I had the Kalbi and it was very good.   Clearly this is more of a "fast food' joint than a sit down place, but the quality of food for the type of restaurant is excellent.

Amazing food - open late - superb staff 
& karaoke allll night! Def try the kalbi the katsu & the Kaluha YUM! also they've got the BEST macaroni salad & I don't usually even eat that stuff but theirs is BOMB!

Pork adobo fried rice is a MUST. If you ever believe any of my reviews, believe this! The pork adobo fried rice is the shit!

Ratings for the rest of the food I tried:

- Lumpia: standard. I could make these better by frying the frozen ones from the store
- Manapua: This appears to be the same brand from Hawaii that is frozen and you just microwave it. Not that it's not good, it is...
- Kalua pig with cabbage: Tasty, but a little too salty for me (and I LURVE salty stuff).
-Mac salad: I can make this better myself, which defeats the purpose of me ordering it.

Overall, I'd probably come back here for the fried rice. It was SO good. Service was good too....both ladies working the counter were super nice. So I'm giving it 3.5 stars.

3.5 fried stars!

I'll def be back here next time I'm in Vegas. I love Hawaiian food and BBQ, but I've never seen adobo fried rice on a menu before, let alone an adobo fried rice omelet! I almost never order an omelette, because it brings to mind the dull, thick, multiple egg dishes at diners. Luckily my lady friend had heard of it before, at this place, and ordered it. I ended up ordering the combo plate with chicken adobo, katsu, and rice. It was good, and a plentiful portion. As soon as they brought her plate to to the table, I knew I'd made a terrible mistake. It looked and smelled delicious, and when I took a sample bite, it was even better! The egg is cooked thinly with lots of chopped green onion in it. For lack of a better term, Chinese style. The fried rice wrapped inside is great, not as greasy as I had been expecting. Even writing this now, I want some! They have plenty of other stuff on the menu from lumpia to musubi to saimin. I'm sure there are other good things, but next time I'm in town, I know exactly what I'm ordering.

comfort food after a long night of drinking.....
this is a great place to get that

I usually order the pork fried rice or adobo omelette to cap off that drinking night
very good, not too greasy....gotta have a little though, hits the spot
lots of good fried rice wrapped in a thin egg wrap or omelette as they call it
lots of carbs to absorb all that bad alcohol!

I have ordered other dishes here, the chicken katsu is decent, curry ok
teriyaki is well, teriyaki, nothing outstanding about it, good though
loco moco is good if you need something a bit heavier than the omelette

place is opened til wee hours of morning too, so great place to hit after leaving that club/bar
try it, you won't be disappointed....

A good local place for when I don't want to drive to far for Hawaiian food. They serve a decent Loco Moco with a thick brown gravy that needs a little more flavor but other wise its filling and the Spam Musubi is good, add the hot mustard, Tabasco. Its all good!
Favorite Dinner... Kolbi Ribs (well done) w/ Macaroni... Service is good, says Hi John every time I come in to eat.  Love

I ordered the mix plate and it had beef, chicken and fish. First bite was really good and maybe because I was hungry. After that I found the food quite sweet. It's like teriyaki sauce everywhere. 

The rice was awesome. It had some kind of oil that made it nice and sticky and shiny. The Mac was yucky. Fish was battered in egg and i don't really like that. I personally don't like pan fried eggs. Chicken was good at least it's normal tasting. The beef was sweet with too much sauce.

Juice was interesting Hawaiian sun. I got the guava nectar.

Not bad but not like wow.
I might come back will see.

Aloha Kitchen is my go to for Hawaiian food even though it is a far drive for me it is totally worth the drive, the food is awesome, customer service is even better, the restaurant is always clean, the seating is good. This place deserves 5 stars!!

I have been frequenting aloha kitsch since high school, around 10-12 years. I used to ditch to here actually lol. 80% of the time you'll see people order the student special which is about $5. It comes this chicken teriyaki, rice, and a soda. My personal fave if I'm super hungry is the kalbi combo or just the kalbi plate. The combo comes with kalbi, chicken katsu, chicken teriyaki, rice, and your choice of mac salad or Kim chee. The kalbi is fricken to die for its so tender and flavorful! I swear I could just sit and eat and eat and eat these ribs lol. You can also order them for catering! It's $40 to feed 15ppl and $90 to feed 30ppl. 

I have seen this place go through so many decorative renovations and I think the current decor is my favorite. They moved the drink station away from the order counter so it helps traffic TREMENDOUSLY! 
OH and don't forget your ID they ALWAYS check it :)

The food was good but I like the restaurant on Charleston Avenue better than the one on Decatur.  Charleston Avenue has better ambience, looks dirty, really cool signs made me feel like I was in Hawaii.    

 I think the food was great.   I think the food was the same as Charleston Avenue but the ambience of the little place just made the meal better.

I was excited to try this place because one of my Hawaiian patient's suggested it. The food itself is delicious and reasonable for the price. I got the local plate which comes with two spam masubis, chicken teriyaki, beef, and mac salad for only $8.99! Everything was flavorful, but we started feeling sick afterwards. We also ordered turon and wish they were fresh rather than straight from a container because the banana was tough to chew.

Allways loved this place. This location is nice and looks like it was newly renovated. Very clean.
Kalbi ribs are juicy and sweet.  Spam musubi are fav(:

If you've never been to Aloha Kitchen, you're missing out, my friends. I flippin' love the food here!

I'm gonna get right into it: this place has the best teriyaki chicken in town. I don't care what they say about L&L having good food (it's ok), THIS IS WHERE YOU GO FOR TERI. When you order the chicken teri plate, you get three pieces of chicken, two balls of rice, and a little bit of mac salad. The mac salad here is the best, and I routinely order an additional serving of mac salad because it's so good!

If you've never had kalbi ribs, you need to. I remember the first time I had kalbi ribs, I thought, "man, these things don't look like what I was expecting..." and then they blew my mind. I recommend you try the Kalbi Combo, too. It's just so delicious. 

Everything here is good. The problem is that since I love the Chicken Teri and Kalbi Combo so much, I usually wind up getting that and not expanding my horizons. I mean, I've had a bunch of other things (katsu!) but I just go back to my favs. 

The prices are affordable, too. I was just there and bought two meals, two drinks, and an extra mac salad for $22 even. It's a really good deal when you consider that you get a lot of food for that amount of money, and it's really delicious, too. 

The place isn't the most high-end establishment in town. So what? It doesn't pretend to be. Their thing is awesome food at a great price, and they really deliver on that front. I've taken a few people there, and they've become addicts, as well. It's just that good!

Wow. I'm so sadden to have to say I will never return here again. I am eating with friends at a booth and a roach creeps up on us while we were seated at the booth. My husband advised the employee and he said he just fumigated so that's why we had a visitor. There was no need for that visitor to come while I was at the table and ruin my experience. So sad they did not do anything about this. I won't be back!
good adobo omelette. i never actually crave the food though with the prices.

Looks like they lowered their quality in meat. This is suppose to be Tapsilog. Looks more like thin sliced beef for a Philly cheesesteak. At least let the customer know while ordering you've changed he meat. I use to get Tapsilog here all the time and it was never like this. At least they changed the order for us. You lowered your quality but kept the same prices.

There was a bit of a line waiting to order and it seemed to move very slowly. They would not accommodate a food allergy by exchanging the meat in one of their dishes. Any other place could do it! The sesame soy salad was very good! Their macadamia banana pancakes are nothing short of delicious! The staff was obviously inexperienced. Where they lacked in service they made up for in it the kitchen. Good food!

A mixed bag. The food is good. I had the kalua pork and cabbage. It was  a little salty but ok. The spam musabi was awesome. You will not leave there hungry.
The karaoke bar had a great host! He would play popular dance songs I in between the singing to keep everyone involved. My biggest disappointment was the bar. Get beer, because they water down the drinks.

I would give them 5 stars but poor service. I orders Kalbi which supposed to come with Kalbi sauce but I guess he forgot so I walk there to ask for Kalbi sauce and instead of get me the sauce first he said he'll be right with me and continue packing Togo order for 20 mins and he messed up so he have to repack it but could've get me the damn sauce first. Really disappointed but overall was okay. I love love love their Kalbi and their spams are good as well :)

After a quick workout at my old school LVAC on West Sahara, I decided to cross the road and hit up an old school Hawaiian food place - Aloha Kitchen.

When I walked in, I was happy to discover that Oxtail Soup is a winter special. It was a no-brainer and I certainly enjoyed it. The oxtail was a little tough and fatty, but the broth had good flavor. Then again, I'm not that picky. Overall, I think the Oxtail Soup at Market Street and even Island Flavor is better, but this one satisfied just fine.

Glad to see Aloha Kitchen is still worth visiting.

Came for an event and was impressed by some dishes but ultimately let down by the one thing I actually ordered. Because I'm lazy I'm gonna make it quick. Get the fried saimin. It's really good. I'd go for some right now if i was near there. Don't get the lau lau. It sucks. Sort of dry and bland.

This is the best Aloha Kitchen we been to. The tables, floors, and bathrooms are always clean, the staff always friendly, and service is on point. Auntie at the counter always remember us and our kids when they come. This is like visiting ohana everytime.

Love the fact they stay open so late. If you want the atmosphere of fun and positive vibes, this is the place you're looking for. Price and quality of food is on point. 

Now as for the cons. This place has none. 

Conclusion, you want a place to be a regular at, again this is the place to add to the list and mark as a fav. Mahalo Auntie to you and the staff. Our ohana will be coming here for generations to come.

The most bullshit fucking place I used to love going here I just moved from New York. They used to run my card like normal now hey have a 5 dollar minimum so I always tell them just charge me 5 . Everyday it's different one person will run my card for less no problem then this fucking asshole young boy won't, then this stupid young bitch won't either. I literally go often and everyday since this bullshit is something different and management is full of shit as well. Why are you all not following the rules if it is one it's because it's some dumb fake shit. Fuck you all and fuck this place you stupid fucks. No one likes to be played with plus there is no sign that says there is a minimum. Not to mention the other day the bathroom had roaches why I go back is because it's fast shit close to where I live but fuck this place any suggestions for a new place fuck these people and their dumb ass fucking games. They would get no stars honestly!

I feel like we've been here before but at the same time it seemed new to me. Lots of parking outside. The place has clearly been around for a while. There's a karaoke bar connected to it branded the same as well. We visited after 830pm and it was a quiet Friday night. The staff was really nice, calling us baby, honey, sweetheart. I'm guilty of doing the same thing. 
I had the bbq chicken, my big son had chicken katsu, the small one had friend saimin, and the hubby had the garlic chicken with gravy, we shared fries and a musubi kids meal. We had some turon and poke...I'm a sucker for register add one and the turon was just staring at me as I ordered. 
We chose dine-in option and were given a number for our table and sat. It's a order then seat yourself type of place. I noticed that they don't keep certain condiments not eh tables, but behind the counter instead. So if you need tobacco or sriracha, ask them! They have it for ya! 
Our orders came our fairly quickly and my bbq chicken was excellent. Poke wasn't that awesome, fried saimin was okay too, but the fries for some reason were soooo good! Fries on point! I can't speak for anything else, as I murdered my bbq chicken plate and turon, so I was too full to sample anything else.
Didn't visit the restroom during this occasion. I'd definitely visit again if we were ever in the immediate area. We were jumping at the trampoline place across the street before we came in this evening.

i guess its more of the "hawaiian experience". With ...um...hip hop music and rap playing.... 

As a person from Honolulu, The atmosphere was nice. Reminded me of home, but  not the food. And the music made me feel like I just walked into a trap of Hawaii food, and the hood. The first time I was there I ordered the adobo. Not bad. That I can't complain about. Theres actually good rice that doesnt taste like it should be fed to a bird.

Who would've thought they would have an Adobo Fried Rice Omelette?!

Well I didn't order it, but my friend did, and it was sooooo good!!!  I ordered the Adobo plate. and that was yummy too (but mines is better HAHA).  The prices are pretty decent here, and you don't wait for you food too long either. 

I'm going back here again the next time I go to Vegas!

Love this place... So many great choices to choose from.  I love both their tapsilog and their adobo omelets.  (Watch out for the bay leaves, though, if you order the adobo omelet.)  This place is open late and is a great place to stop by after the clubs.

Waited almost an hour for food. Come to find out it was sitting on the counter the WHOLE F'ING TIME! They saw us waiting. No one cared to ask us if we needed help or if we were waiting for food. Never going there again. Don't order take out. They'll forget you were there.

Came in for dinner at 7:12pm on August 5th , and JANE helped us at the cashier , and specifically asked if they sale BACON , and she gave me a look like "What are you talking about?" I was already annoyed that I had to wait , if you don't know what bacon is then I don't know what kind of style you're living! And then I repeated myself numerous times and she asked "What is that?" REALLY? So i just ordered the Portuguese sausage eggs over easy and rice ! BECAUSE I asked if they had bacon and she literally asked me "what's that?" Overall I come ALL the time and everybody else knew what I what I like to order , but apparently she didn't know what bacon was!
Always a great time when I visit this place! Obsessed with the staff, and I could live off the spam masubi here. Mix plates are the way to go.

Aloha kitchen and bar 

My friend ordered the Portuguese fried rice Omlet. He said it was good and tasty. He said it was a large portion for a single person. The rice and eggs were cooked properly.

I ordered The local plate. It had 
Terry beef and chicken, Mac n cheese, 2 spam musubi. This was a lot for one person. Everything was tasting. The chicken and beef were great. Both were moist and juice. The 2 spam musubis were filling. Drinks are Pepsi flavors with free refills. 

The parking is shared with other business. But there's plenty of parking available. There is Music playing is low, not to loud but you can hear it in the background. Modern theme style decor with bamboo accents.  There's a TV but it wasn't on. 


I would recommend this place to my friends and family if they're ever in Vegas. I'll be coming back here once I come back to Vegas.

Since multiple concurrent projects and Life In General have kept me up a lot more than my normal Xtr33m Vampiric Evil schedule necessitates, Aloha Kitchen has been my lifesaver when the Triscuits and Dack Janiels in my desk threaten to detach my fingernail grip on sanity. I've discovered that one can play "Adobo Omelet" drinking games, i.e. if you consume a bay leaf, take a shot! The styrofoam box it comes in is also ludicrously heavy that I can't help but giggle uncontrollably in hentai-schoolgirl bursts when I swear I can't take another bite, oh no the smell itself is making me nauseous, how the hell can someone eat this much in one sitting......then pop the fridge open after 2 hours and praise God that it's still there! Make sure to keep the rice cooker on standby when you get the Loco Moco; their particular blend is beaucoup SAUCY!  And will necessitate additional rice to quell the sometimes-salty sensations. Local Plate last night got a lot of seaweed musubi wrap in my teeth; perfect for the post-second-date makeout session. 

Student specials (sub-$5), Tapsilog in the morning, and consistent Chicken Katsu give me many reasons to list the Kitchen among the daily expenditures. Now if only I could complain about "it's too umame, could you cut back on the umame?" with a straight face, then I know I've won at life.

I wish I could give more stars, but my stomach can't agree with that executive decision. This is my usual late night go-to spot for my lunch break, when I forget my lunch that is. I really only like this place because it is open late (open til 3 AM) and the workers are generally pretty nice. This place does get pretty slammed, so placing an order over the phone can be pretty difficult. I usually order the Local Plate, but lately the quality has just gone down for me. The chicken katsu is hit or miss, along with the teriyaki chicken. This spot was a hidden gem for me when I first moved to Vegas 5 years ago, and it wasn't til I worked across the street I was able to recognize the walls of this place. I'll be back, hopefully things are a bit different next time.

Yea after eating here and all this excitement from delivery...Wahhh we don't deliver to Trop and Decatur. WELL DAMN YOU WOMAN..... So everyone else pretty much said what's on the menu. It's Hawaiian food from your Spam Musubi to your Kahlua pork...But one thing stops my heart. Calling all Filipinos.... 
ADOBO FRIED RICE OMELETTE...
WTF!!!!????
Ohhh yea Garlicky pork and chicken adobo goodness. fried in rice and stuffed in a huge omelette egg. Oh yea baby....Slather me up in butter and smear mayonnaise on my left toe. Just makes the sun shinier - the grass greener....and somalian kids having a whopper jr. Yea that's what greatness is. Did I mention I hate eating common shit? Ok sure it's a lil salty. But expect it from the soy sauce and vineger of the Adobo....you know what balances it... White rice....Mmmm White Rice....

Not my favorite Hawaiian place around town but they are conveniently located and seem to be close by when I am craving Saimin as they have four locations-

1.) South Decatur
2.) South Maryland Parkway
3.) East Charleston
4.) West Suset Road

What I do like is the diversity of the menu. The menu consists of a variety of Hawaiian, Filipino, Chinese, Japanese, Korean and American items (yes, there are cheeseburgers!). My favorite dishes from here are the Chicken Katsu, Saimin, Poke and Kalbi Ribs. If you want to try a bit of everything I would recommend the Aloha plate ($8.49) which comes with Chicken Katsu, teriyaki beef and teriyaki chicken. The adobo fried rice omelet ($7.69) is also another popular item. 

Although it is not listed on their menu they sometimes have an Oxtail Soup which Filipinos call Bulalo. It is really good here and I recommend you ordering it if they offer it.

Today I was able to call in my order and pick it up on my way home from work. I was able to save time and skipped the long line and waiting at the busy restaurant.

Aloha Kitchen stalks my dreams...  I wake with a rumbling belly and a craving for macaroni salad and rice.

My head fills with thoughts of kalua pig, adobo fried rice, spam masubi and loco moco heart attack platters....

I am addicted.  I will visit again on all future LV trips.  Best Hawaiin food I have enjoyed since Da Kines closed down in San Diego.

The fact you can get some classic Filipino fare is icing on the cake.

Bomb food, cheap prices.  Please open an Aloha Kitchen in LA!

It's Saturday 4.1.17....1230pm-ish ..long morning of games..we decided to come eat our comfort food...Hawaiian food...so last time we went to Aloha kitchen is when my cousin was working here over 3 yrs ago..  

 
ATMOSPHERE  - When we came...atmosphere is nice...wasn't too busy and the dining room was clean....(but they got really really busy when we sat down...the rush came in...)

CLEANLINESS  - the place is clean..except the coffee station was kind of messy.

CUSTOMER SERVICE ..they are still polite and friendly 

PRICES - the prices are reasonable for what ur getting...however I am extremely picky abt my Hawaiian food...

FOOD- So let's to get to the main reason why I came.....The food kinda went down from what I remember... prices are good......but the food aww man...small kine not too good this round.. 

The breakfast plate- Portuguese sausage eggs and rice...First the rice was mushy..the eggs should have been scrambled with cheese so they made it into an omelet looking style and put a regular American cheese slice..really?!
The Portuguese sausage did not taste like Portuguese sausage.. it didn't have that chili pepper saltiness to it like a Portuguese sausage should have..call me picky but I know my sausages

My husband has a Bento box ...mushy rice the spam was thick and not all the way cooked and the teriyaki sauce that was on the meat kind of tastes like it was from a can...
The only thing that was actually good..was the  chicken skewers..but they were a little raw looking...


I had to give 2 stars (my husband didnt feel they deservd that...) ...but i dont feel they no longer represent the true Hawaiian style food ...almost cutting corners..
...

THIS IS A MUST STOP WHENEVER I'm IN VEGAS.

4 words: ADOBO FRIED RICE OMELETTE. 

Sure I can easily make this at home. But something about the dish that just isnt the same if I was to make it at home. It's actually good here! 

Everything else is pretty good too. I've had their tapsilog, saimin, longsilog. All good but again 4 words: ADOBO FRIED RICE OMELETTE. Geeeeet it!

This place is SO AWESOME. After a late night, this is my next morning go to place (of course i've already had pho at the 24 hour place at 3am already so that's not an option). 

I ordered the spam musubi and adobo. The adobo is so tender and perfect. Even in california, I have trouble finding good filipino food , so you could probably get a sense of my excitement when I had this. The spam musubi is like any normal spam musubi. It might have a bit more rice than usual, but I just use it to eat the adobo. The food here is very inexpensive and is very good. I love this place! Such a gem inside this plaza.

Always my fave spot when on the late night hunger. Amazing employees who always welcomes you and if you come often will become your friend! I've been going here for years and I love it.

Fave dish is adobo and chicken katsu! They already know when I walk in. Hell, even when I don't come in for a long awhile, they still remember. Haha. Anyway, everything that I've tried is always wonderful. Cooked to perfection and served warm and fresh. Can never go wrong with aloha! :D
I love their poke bowls.. Tha lady at the counter is really nice and helpful.. highly recommend!!

Continuing on the search to find a fabulous serving of pork lau lau, I was brought to Aloha Kitchen on S. Decatur Blvd.  Pulling into the lot, I recall seeing this place on yelp and was anxious to get my turn at it.  It's pretty crowded for a late Friday night and people are starting to pile in.

We join the line and perused the menu above.  The BF convinces me to go for the Hawaiian Plate at $8.99.  It's Kalua Pig and Pork Lau Lau, so this way he gets to try some of the kalua pig too!  This comes with two scoops of rice and one scoop of mac salad.  The BF ops for the Kalbi Combo at $7.99.  This give us Kalbi, Katsu, and Chicken Teriyaki.  It also comes with the standard two scoops of white rice and one scoop of mac salad.  

I should mention, I've been to my share of Hawaiian joints, but my sister takes the cake.  She definitely makes it a point to try out any new ones that she comes across.  She also always substitutes the two scoops of rice and one scoop of mac salad for an additional scoop of mac and one less rice.  This is usually never a problem, and if anything, they might charge a bit more for the mac salad.  Well, I asked if I could do this.  The cashier had to ask another woman, and she in turn had to ask another guy (the manager/owner) I assume.  He flat out said no.  Wow.  They tried explaining something about not charging me for the rice, so they can't do that.  Anyway, I think I was just put off with the whole "No." answer.  They could have said yes and said they would charge me for the substitution, which I probably would have agreed to anyway.  

We got our number, helped ourselves to beverages and condiments and took a seat in a booth.  One of the servers soon headed our way with my order.  Just as she was about to place it on the table, all this liquid came spilling out onto the floor and table from the plate.  (Wtf?)  She apologized and went to retrieve a towel to clean up the mess.  I was fine with the spill and clean up, my concern was with where all the liquid came from?!  I guess my Pork Lau Lau must have come out a bath, because that was dripping wet.  I ended up  pouring all this additional liquid off my plate into another plate before my rice and mac salad got too soggy from all this 'juice' sitting on my dish.  I unraveled my lau lau in search of my pork and took my first bite.  For being soggy, the meat was rather tough and the whole dish had no taste.  I ended up pouring tons of shoyu all over the dish.  There was no fatty bits either to give it any flavor.  Very disappointing on the pork lau lau part.  The kalua pig faired a bit better, but not by much.  It started out well, but as I got deeper into it, there was a lot of tough pieces that I ended up spitting out.  Overall, my dish was pretty disappointing.  I wouldn't go back here for any pork lau lau at all.

I was about halfway through my order before the BF's order finally arrived.  (This is never a good thing.)  His was better, in his opinion.  He had a decent experience with his order at least.  The Chicken Teriyaki had a sweeter sauce than what I'm used to, but that's probably why this dish does well here. 

The mac salad was better than some of the other places I've been to, so that was a good thing.  

There's the Aloha Bar next door and there's karaoke on Friday nights.  You'll see the servers bringing orders in next door if you're dining in.  

They do offer delivery, it's a $10 minimum and if you get their flyer, you'll find a 15% coupon on there. I asked if they had any business cards, which they were out of.  When the cashier asked the manager/owner if he had any, he asked "Why?"  (Uh, 'cuz I'm going to yelp this place, that's why!)

When it comes down to it, Aloha Kitchen will continue to do well.  They are open later than some of the other Hawaiian establishments around town (5 am on Fridays and Saturdays I believe!) and they have a surplus of young customers coming in to chow down.  They have two other locations, one on E. Charleston and the other on S. Maryland Parkway.  I just know that if I return, I won't be getting any pork lau lau, that's for sure.

A perfect place for Las Vegas.
Open late at night for those of us that work late at night.

Very friendly staff.
While I'm not really big into Hawaiian food, there still are a few menu items I can have that satisfies my hunger. It's also reasonably priced when you're having one of those nights losing money to the blackjack tables.

There are also pretty cool people that hang out here and eat.

One of the better places to eat at in Vegas!
Aloha kitchen is my favorite place to go for Hawaiin food and a great time! Highly recommend!

This is one of my go to when I want hawaiian food. Im no expert but i love their food. My favorite being kalbi ribs plate.  My boyfriend is a huge fan of their Kalbi combo (terriyaki chicken, katsu chicken , ribs). My boyfriends second fav is their fried chicken. Price is good. Service is fast and if you live nearby they even deliver. They are also open late.

I first tried this place when i lived in las vegas. When i go back to visit its one of those places that makes me feel like im home again. Flavor is still the same.
Bombbbb Hawaiian foooood. I would definitely come back for their chicken katsu. Their spam musubi was pretty good too. Lots of space to eat and chill.

Absolutely love everything on the menu! 
The staff are ok....not rude but no top notch either. 
Reason for minus 1 star, my order took forever and the joint ain't even half full.

I can always count on Aloha Kitchen and Bar to feed my hunger at midnight or later.  Other than casinos, this is the only place I know of that serves Hawaiian local food till 4:30am.  The only downer is how far this place is.  I live in Old Henderson and this restaurant and bar location is on Sahara and Decatur.  No place is far though, when you're on a local food fix!

Last night I had one of those cravings, so I came by to visit everyone at Aloha Kitchen.  I've been to this location many times because of the karaoke bar next door.  Everyone is AH-MAZE-ING.  First off, you're greeted by their bouncer, Greg.  Then you have Shawn at the bar.  Probably the coolest guy you'll ever meet.  Jovane (sorry if I misspelled your name) was the cocktail server and super sweet and Izzy is the KJ.  Very entertaining.  In the restaurant, there's Cyndel who's been a part of Aloha Kitchen for over 10 years.  Everyone's just full of Aloha and treats you like family.

Tonight I got the chicken katsu, spam musubi and the Shanghai lumpia.  The katsu is super crispy and good.  What I really like though, is the katsu sauce. Best katsu sauce I've had.  It's more tangy and savory, rather than sweet.  To me, it compliments the katsu very well.  With the musubi, they add their teriyaki sauce to the spam so it flavors the rice.  Packed with a lot of flavor.  The lumpia is small and filled with pork.  Served with a sweet chili dipping sauce.  Super good with a beer next door.  

One thing that I could do without is the constant fighting this place has on late nights.  Lately though, there hasn't been any sketchy activities.  All in all, I love visiting this place because of the food and people.  If you're ever in the area, come down and check this place out.

I just need something heavy and comforting to sop up some drinks I had and some adobo omelette sounded good.

The BF and I shared:

Adobo Omelette- pretty good and quite large and filling. It hit the spot I was looking for.

Local Plate: chicken and beef teriyaki, 2 spam musubis- the meats and all are fine, mac salad is fine, but I don't like the thick teriyaki they use. Unfortunately, they pour the sauce on top of the meats and put some in the musubi so it wasn't that great of a plate for me. If I knew then I would have asked it without and maybe it would be better. 

This was my 2nd time here. It's been a while since the last visit was less than stellar (they forgot some of the elements on my plate, added a meat we didnt order on another plate) and I remember thinking it was just okay tasting.

 I think it's alright for late night eats, but there are other better Hawaiian plate places for daytime.

Walked in and noticed a customer sort of complaining and arguing with the the cashier. The cook was eavesdropping and the customer got mad. The cook seemed like a Latino man talking under his breath. I noticed the cushions on the seating area torn and the tables a little dirty. 

I ordered a bento box and since I don't eat beef asked to substitute the meat for either chicken or more spam. The cashier seemed clueless, and went to the back and asked the cook, not a manager or owner, but the Latino cook. 

Reading some of the reviews while waiting for my meal leaves me wondering if this place should be called "Aloha" kitchen? Do the cashiers know what Aloha means? I felt a smile and a warm welcome greeting would have been a better touch than questioning me why I was asking if the food here was authentic.

Ok, so I get my meal, take a bite and am surprised. It tastes good. My friend liked his Katsu and the rice was perfect. 

Overall, the food is better than most but the service and attitude needs to go! I'm being fair, the food is a 4plus and service a 2. 

Foodies; it's a place worth trying, the food taste good! 

PS, the teriyaki pork taste like back home in Hawaii.. Nice

There are Hawaiian restaurants everywhere in Las Vegas, but this is one of the more "ono" spots in my opinion!

* Chicken Katsu - Can never go wrong with deep friend strips of chicken and rice, right?
* Adobo Omelet - Scrambled egg wrap around rice mixed with shredded pork adobo.  It's in the shape of a burrito and is pretty huge (although I can easily gulf down one myself!).  I know a lot of people hype this dish up, but to me, it lives up to the hype.  It tastes like home cookin!
* Loco Moco - Gotta love hamburger meat smothered in gravy with egg all over?  I've tried many a loco moco and Aloha Kitchen has one of the best I've tried in Vegas (best I'd ever had is in Hawaii).
* Oxtail Soup - Delicious and a must try if you can.  
* Saimin - A little too salty for me.
* Tapsilog - Tapa, egg, and garlic fried rice just like my dad's standard breakfast.

Prices are reasonable and the décor is cute (there's a location on Sunset that is aesthetically nicer) .  My one complaint is that the food can take long sometimes and the service is par.  There were a couple of times we got the wrong order/order never called when eating there and a couple of times we got a cashier who just seemed angry all the time.  This could have been due to the busyness of the place though since it does get pretty crowded late nights.   

We frequent the bar next door too.  They have a pretty great song selection, although it can be hard to get on the mic on busy Friday and Saturday nights.  Drinks are normal priced, but the karaoke is free. Have some drinks there then walk over next door immediately after for a complete night out!

I ordered the spam musubi plate and my brother ordered chicken katsu plate, both were delish. I've only had l&l to compare and I have to say that the chicken katsu here is really really good. The flavor and breading was perfect, even had the perfect crunch. I always go for the spam musubi I grew up eating them in l.a.  and it takes me back every time. 

You'll always get good service too, food is made timely. Next time I come I want to make a review on their bar, got too full from the food this time around. 

Look forward to eat here when I'm in the area or atleast pick up and go.

Decided to try this place for some late Sunday evening eats with a friend. Bonus: Open late daily. I would probably prefer Island Style but they close at 8pm and not open on Sundays. Place looked clean enough and prices reasonable. I had combo of Chicken Katsu & Chicken curry. My friend had the bbq combo(Katsu, teri chicken & kalbi). Both our katsu's were a bit overdone because the outside was pretty dark brown and tasted accordingly. The 2 scoops of rice looked more like 3. The mac salad was decent. I had a taste of my friend's teri chicken and I could tell it wasn't marinated bbq/teri chicken I'm used to having back in Hawaii growing up. It was just grilled chicken that had a lightly colored sweet sauce on top. The katsu did come with the thick, sweet tangy traditional japanese katsu sauce.
I would come back to perhaps to try other items here. The first visit though was just ok.

The food is good, but definitely not great.  If you want good food, a lot of it, for a very reasonable price...go here.  The service and the decor are okay.  You order at the counter and the food it delivered.  It got there quickly.  Overall, it was good, but definitely not memorable.

This is one of those places you gotta go off the strip. As an islander, this is straight up comfort food for me. We went and got the spam musubi, kalua pig and cabbage, and the adobo fried rice omlette.

Spam musubi - typical verison. No furukake though.

Kalua pig & cabbage - pretty good for a fast food version of this dish. Savory, sweet pork mixed with the bitterness of the cabbage is a mix that I love. Meat is moist and tender. Something I'd probably order each time.

Adobo fried rice omlette - very flavorful dish. Mmm...good stuff. Everyone else has pretty much covered it, so I don't feel the need to say much.

Overall, service was friendly and punctual, food was good quality, good portion size, especially for the price. I'd definitely hit this place up for breakfast on my next trip to LV.

Oh boy oh boy.... Where do I begin..  I saw their advertisement for about 2 weeks for their xmas day buffet for $15.  The list of food sounded great and included many typical hawaiian items.  I arrived there around 7.  It was fairly quiet/empty and figured most people came there earlier. There were probably only 20 people in there when I arrived.  
1st off the service was great. The employees were very nice and I definitely expected that being in a hawiian restaurant.  The place was also very clean and that too was not an issue.  

The food is the main issue here.  When I walked upto the buffet, the sushi table had 3 basic rolls on there and was ok at best.  The lumpia was probably the most decent thing I ate.  I was in total shock when I saw the spam musubi.  They had it all nice looking, all cut in half in nice big pieces (this would've been perfect but NOOOO they screwed it up.) They had some sort of sauce on ALL of it. The problem is you CAN'T put sauce on a rice item like this that is sitting there.  I had one bite and it completely fell apart in my hand because the sauce had made the whole thing mushy.  

The katsu was overcooked and dried out.  The halfway decent stir fry veggies were sorta ok but they were sitting under a heat lamp and getting mushy and all in all lacked flavor.  The curry was very bland. I tried a little of a few other dishes and again everything was bland and blah.  I was completely disappointed in the macaroni salad. WOW it had nooooo flavor to it. It was just simply mayonaisse.  

The desserts were store bought donuts, some chocolate chip cookies, and some funky brownies.  and btw I saw other people sitting around me making faces too about the food. 

There's a few problems here. #1 let's compare apples to apples... Aloha kitchen vs L&L Hawaiian. This buffet gave me a really good idea of what their food is like if I ordered it off their regular menu (vs buffet style) I have been to L&L many many times and wow they are definitely a LOT better then Aloha.  I have tried several things on their menu and everything has been flavorful, yummy, not over cooked and their macaroni salad is great too.   1 out of 10.. Aloha you're a 1.  L&L a 10.
There was nothing good about the food at Aloha and I was VERY disappointed.  Now comparison #2.  Although now I'm comparing apples to oranges but still.  

Aloha vs buffet @ asia which is just minutes up the street.  Aloha, you can not charge $15 for what you put on that buffet with that kind of quality.  Buffet @ Asia is WAY better then you in quality and selection for the same price.  Just sushi alone puts you to shame (and they don't have any fantastic sushi either but it's way better then yours)  and with Sushi Mon being 10 min up the street as well, they blow both places out of the water.  

It's very tough to run a good restaurant, but if L&L can have almost all the same menu items and they do it right with quality, and taste and the same price, then so can you. Aloha kitchen.... You're a discrace to good hawaiian food.  

I will continue my business at L&L

- Been coming here since 2010 because the place is a good value.
- Large portion sizes, good food, reasonable prices, open 7 days a week late in to the night (whereas Island Style closes early and isn't even open on Sundays  http://www.yelp.com/biz/island-style-las-vegas).
- Staff is friendly and there's a self-serve soda dispenser so free refills when I'm eating there.

I love this place! The combination plate is my favorite , it's beef & chicken teriyaki with rice . You can ask with veggies on the side. I personally thought that they would be fresh but they were steamed , still good though & of course I always get the macaroni salad. It's my favorite ! I've been coming here for years and I highly recommend it :)

A place to hit up after a drunken night out or if you're in the mood for some karaoke. I personally have not done the latter so can't say much for what goes on in there.

Food is okay, you can get a lot of Filipino Hawaiian staples like Loco Moco, Spam Musubi, Kalbi, Lumpia. Ordered the Tapsilog a couple of times, flavors were definitely on point but the beef itself was tough so it was disappointing. There isn't an option to do garlic rice either which is vital for a Tapsilog in my opinion. They have plenty to offer on the menu so I'm sure you can find something that will appease your palate. The place needs serious updating though. But when you're drunk and hungry it's the least of your worries I'm sure.

Man this spot has been my favorite Hawaiian spot in town since high school and college. Their pricing is just perfect for you to try even on a low income budget. 
There teriyaki sauce is the best bar none. 
The only thing left for me to try there is their Luau pork. 
I'm waiting for the winter to come. I don't like eating soups in the summer time. They make me sweat. 
Loyal fan for life. I wish they would open one by centennial hills. Lulu BBQ just isn't the same.
Came here with friends. Filipino fusion food. Had the rice with corn beef hash. They ran out of Tapa. =/ Food was delicious after drinking all night before. First meal of my vegas trip.

Want the best Hawaiian islander Food????? GO TO THIS PLACE. I seriously love this place, Kalbi Combo is my dish. It's filling & so good. But i can munch on some spam musubi if I'm in a hurry. Customer service is great. Food is delicious. The best restaurant hands down.

2016 Yelp 100 Review Challenge 86/100

Not bad, but definitely not my go to place for Hawai'ian food. Trust me, I'm from Hawai'i and there are much better places around town. 

It's weird but some of my friends who are originally from California seem to like this place. :-P

If I do come here, I don't get Hawai'ian style food. Last time I was here I got a cheeseburger. I wouldn't go out of my way for this but it was good, huge cheeseburger. 

This one has a karaoke bar, the other ones don't. So it has it's appeal if you're into that.

Perhaps the attached bar should have lead me to believe being intoxicated was the key to a great meal.....

The 2 stars are for the kalua pork as it was delicious and plentiful. 

I noticed the mixed reviews but still thought it could be worth the stop.  I'll break it down. 

Ordered the hawaiian plate with an order of spam musubi. 

Musubi was like no musubi I've ever had. A thick chewy wrap of seaweed around a thin piece of spam and rice. Had some sort of sweet sauce in their as well.  Not a good spin on musubi. 

Mac salad...now this was almost good, but wasn't  ..really the Mac salad makes the meal in my opinion. 

Lau Lau ...where to begin..well I'm no expert, I don't believe a giant pile of leaves and green mush (see pic) over a tiny bit of the inside stuff is the way to do it. 

Perhaps they make something worth eating, this wasn't 

To top it off when my meal came I asked for Siracha and it never came. .....

Should I return it will be for a drink in the bar...perhaps they make a great Mai Tai

I absolutely love this place!!!! The beef bowl is awesome! Always so flavorful and juicy!! They do not put potatoes in their Mac salad which makes this anti potato girl super happy! The lumpia is my favorite! The staff is always super friendly and the service is quick!
Go to spot for Marvin. But wonton soup is terrible they use pot stickers and miso broth!

Hate dropping a 5 star review down, especially down to a 3 star...

But the food just isn't the same anymore.  The value is still there, since it is still fairly cheap food, but the quality has went down.

Not sure if I caught a new cook or just a bad run, but the place was very slow and my food just didn't have the flavor it did before.

I need another Hawaiian spot to check out...please msg me if you have one

I did not eat any food, so this review is only about the service, location, and bar menu.

The drinks were hardly alcoholic, which made their $6 price seem higher than it was.  The bartender also seemed to favor large groups of regular karaoke patrons, and left me waiting at the bar for quite a while on two occasions.

The karaoke DJ also seemed to favor the larger groups of regulars.  I was here for a work party with a large group, but many of our song submissions were delayed in favor of other people's requests.  The "regulars" also seemed to favor ballads, which sort of killed the mood, but I understand the house can't control that too much.
I love their korean bbq chicken, but can only give it 3 stars because of the constant gristle I discover.
Craving for local food as I yelped this place and tastes like the food back home in Hawaii. Ate breakfast here and my kids and Hubby was satisfied and content after .

Best local Hawaiian spot in Vegas, even better then the California..... this place though has a lot of filipno infused dishes so if you are not into that sort of thing and prefer more japanese / hawaiian then the Cal is for you.

Best thing about Aloha Kitchen is it is open super late and has a bar/lounge next door with alcohol. Food is good and the prices are better and the portions are generous. Adobo/Katsu combo is my favortie with portuguese sausage masubi. The Hawaiian Iced Tea is made super sweet though and the sun juices are a little pricier then the ABC store; but thats about the only gripes i have with the place.

As mentioned, the bar next door usually plays local top 40 and sometimes island jams and reggae, the drinks are mixed well and priced just right. They even got slots and video poker! 

if your looking for a grub spot away from the strip, i would definitely go here, you will not regret it!
Aloha Kitchen is somewhere you have to go to when in Vegas. The Adobo Fried Rice Omelette... Bomb diggity! Can't go wrong with that one!

My friends and I ordered a lot of things from this place and shared our food family style.

We ordered the adobo fried rice omelette, macaroni salad, chicken BBQ, spam musubi, chicken katsu, kalua pig and katsu combo, and the loco moco.  Some of these were good, others okay (and needed more flavoring).  If you never had Hawaiian food before, I would definitely give it a try at least once.

Stopped in on Friday night/Saturday morning around 1 am for some karaoke, since the place we were at closed early.

Not too bad...I'm afraid I might have been a bit too intoxicated to really provide a very detailed review, but here's what I remember: 

Drinks:  
Kind of expensive...$28 for 2 beers, and 3 well shots.  
Karaoke:  fun...but the KJ had a pretty sizable queue, and sang 2 songs himself within about 7 minutes of each other.  As a KJ at other venues myself...you don't do that.  You don't sing in the queue unless you have less than 8 people singing.  
Also, there is a sign on the KJ booth that says "2 drink minimum."  
WHAT?  I know most people like to drink before singing, but what if your DD wants to sing?  Is it 2 drinks for the whole party?  Per person?  I don't get it...

Staff:  awesome.  When they were closing down, my friend and I were waiting for our very drunken men to finish in the bathroom.  The staff didn't know this, and came over and said they were closing...when we said we were waiting on the boys, they started joking around with us about "what are they doing in there?" (to which my very clever friend said "Hopefully not sword fighting.")  They were gracious, and very nice.  

I'd come back and give it another go...I'd like to find out more about the drink minimum for karaoke...

Four words:  ADOBO FRIED RICE OMELET!

That alone is the DELICIOUS hallmark of this wonderful hole-in-the-wall Filipino-Hawaiian restaurant inside the UNLV campus.  The huge-size for a $7 value is worth it.  As an east coast tourist who came here on a word-of-mouth referral from my cousin who's been to Vegas a zillion times, I just had to come here and believe it.  I hope you can believe it when you come here.

Also the spam musubi, a slice of grilled spam with a bed rice and sauce around a big maki wrap, is a win!

I went  to Aloha Kitchen and bar last week and had a blast, The food was amazing and you have the best of Hawaiian and the Philippines. The owner Liza and her husband was there and they introduced themselves, I really enjoyed the hospitality. I had a drink from the bar and overall was very happy with Aloha Kitchen. I lived in Hawaii for 5 years and this place made me feel like I was back on the island. I can't wait to go back because there are so many items on the menu I want to try. Thanks Aloha Kitchen see ya soon

I haven't ate at any Hawaiian/Filipino fusion places here yet and this has to be a first! They had a selection of foods that I was unsure of what to get, whether it was that I was craving filipino food or hawaiian food. So I went for the combination mix plate, which came with a piece of teriyaki chicken, steak, and mahimahi fish. I saw other people order the Adobo omelette and I would probably come back again to order that. It was huge and looked amazing.

One of Vegas' little gems... a fusion of Hawaiian/Filipino food. They have all of the things you would normally find at Hawaiian fast food places like L&L but the one thing I highly recommend that I haven't seen anywhere else is the adobo omelette: pork adobo fried rice all wrapped around fried egg. So delicious and huge... drool.

Great because its hawaiian food open late but terrible consistency. Theres times where my rice is just so watery, feels like it may be a couple ounces away from being a porridge, if your eating a rice dish sometimes rice can make or break your entree. There is times when the chicken comes out looking and feeling like a raw defrosted chicken even when ordered skinless its so flimsy like its only been cooked for a few seconds. Another bad thing about this place is how they run your food. If theres more than one person sitting at a table i dont think one person should get their food 5-10 min before the others. Its just wrong going to eat with someone and basically they eat without you or you without them.. Or they wait and by the time yours or their food comes yours is already cold. Other than that when the food is cooked right its very delicious. They have very good potential of being one of the best hawaiian places in town but consistency kills.

My regular place for Hawaiian style food! Very good! I've been here 4 times with in 3 weeks. That should say how I love this place. The saimin is soooo good, and the French fries are always fresh and crunchy.

Awesome Place! Work in the same parking lot where they're located. First time here. Automatically noticed how clean the place it and the workers are super friendly and well groomed. Food came out fast and its is awesome 11/10 totally coming back here again and again :)

Since Vegas has a huge Hawaiian population, there are a lot of Hawaiian restaurants out here.  I've eaten a lot of Hawaiian food out here..but I didnt really like the food too much @ this particular restaurant. I didnt go to this location, I went to the one off of Maryland Pkway, near UNLV.

First time eating here was good. This time not so much. I got the mixed teriyaki plate and my friend got Spicy Beef. The beef was disgusting. First of all it was chopped up which was not how the picture looked on the website and you can tell it had been pre cooked and sitting around. The beef was kinda gray in color so definitely old meat. Lupia and Spam musubi were good. Too many other restaurants in the area so I likely won't ever eat here again. Oh yeah.....my stomach hurts now. I'll upload pictures when I figure out how. No option to do so..

New management new owners suck here the old hawaiian knew was better now owned buy fobs or filipino!! I have no problems with  filipino cause I am one myself  !! I remember when they were generous on food portion I went here today was totally disappointed with the food portion this new owners gave like talk about being greedy go to island flavor food is much better and there food portions are really huge

so when we finally get here, from the outside its like 'ready for some aloha in vegas' when i walk thru the doors its more like 'NOloha'  lol   

spacious eatery thats feels more like a filipino eatery in nevada than a Hawaiian themed restaurant in Vegas.  

bleh on the design, good color on the walls and all but they couldve gone to Aloha Swapmeet to buy some decor to really make this place 'pop'. 

nice menu choices, i guess   ...hawaii esque

they got a karaoki bar here too so thats gotta be fun at some point.

line up, order, find a table, food brought out to you
FOOD is OUTSTANDING!!!   ..has that home cooked flavor.   it was ery shocking to me   lol
basically a better quality than the food of L&L. price comparable to that of JolliBee. 
they got MACADAMIA NUT PANCAKES!   try the hash! loco moco has yummy gravy   ...all good for that added hypertension and high chilesterol level!
OK Hawaiian fix. Crappy music. Semi nice people working there. Used to be a lit better.

The food is way better here then any other spot and the service is great. Got the local plate last time and it was amazing today got the chicken katsu and it's another amazing but I can live off the spam musbi the price is great for what u get.

Delicious food! There is not a bad dish on the menu. I prefer the local platter. They Spam Musubi is a must to order as well, no matter what you order. The place is always very clean and the staff is friendly. You should definitely check it out if you are looking to try something different and out of the ordinary. The prices are really good as well. Pretty cheap considering the portions they give you.

First I'll say the good things. I ordered the eggrolls appetizer and that was delicious! The place looked clean and our waiter was tentative. 

Now the bad things. I bought a Dr. Pepper in the restaurant and was told I couldn't take it in the bar area. The soda had to have a different cup. They didn't have Dr. Pepper on the bar side so I had to choose something else. I mean really I just bought this from you guys. Who cares where I consume it? My friend and I went there for karaoke on a Friday night. BIG MISTAKE! I will never go here again. They falsely advertise karaoke. We go there at 8p.,m and didn't sing until an hour later. Then we submitted another song and it was not called on until after 11:20p.m. I mean really there were not that many singers. Also other singers got to sing two times in a row, when I waited two hours to sing one other song. I had to drive my friend home and I was tired of waiting. I got home at midnight with one song sang. The DJ whatever you want to call him, talked too much, played too much dance music and had a dance off and a person celebrating their birthday come up and have a sick dance of three women around him. It understand it's his show but fix your website. Say it's karaoke, dancing and partying. My friend told the DJ we were leaving soon and he said he'd move our song up. Well three dance songs later that lasted 10 minutes and another singer he had not called us up yet. So we left. This is Vegas! Why can't there be a good karaoke place without the party? I come to sing not watch a guy air hump and stage and dirty dancing.

Not sure why I didn't review this place years ago. An old friend from Hawaii who lives in Vegas introduced me and my bestie, who also grew up in Hawaii to this little gem. Every time I'm in Vegas I come here. 

The kalbi is my fave and a lot of he menu is Filipino dishes made right. My bestie gets her spam musubi (which I don't eat anymore, but she says it legit tastes Hawaii style). 

It's difficult to get Hawaiian Sun drinks on the East Coast especially my fave, passion orange flavor. When I'm in Vegas I get several cans from Aloha and put them in my hotel fridge! I also have to admit I've packed some and brought it back to FL once. I grew up drinking that stuff on the daily.

This may not be fine dining, but it reminds me of the plate lunches back home in Hawaii and a trip to Vegas isn't the same unless I stop in.

I think it's great that this place is open until 3AM because my boyfriend and I don't get off work til 1AM. If we're not too tired then we'll drive from Green Valley to here for some chicken katsu or adobo.

On our most recent visit here, we both ordered the adobo and chicken katsu combination plate to go. The chicken katsu was good but the adobo was SALTY.  By the time I got to the adobo, I ran out of rice. And the only other rice I had at home was the boil-in-a-bag rice that I buy just for my dog. So I decided to save the adobo for the next day and make a sandwich out of it. I've had their chicken curry in the past and I remembered it as being quite good.

The service is always great with plenty of seating and there's plenty of parking.

Haven't been here in a while because my last experience was bad. Unfortunately not much has changed. The rice (a staple of the 808 plate lunch) was dry and tasted old. The Teri chix was not marinated- instead just some sticky Teri sauce was globbed over it. And the portions got smaller. Definitely not a go back to place. Sigh-guess I'll have to make the drive to Isle Sushi on Eastern.

I love this place. The chicken is one of the best I've ever had, i love the skin on chicken. I come here every time i come visit from cali as it reminds me of my unlv days. But i ordered a side of rice for $2.50 last night and this is all i got LOL if i knew that would be all I'd get I would've just ordered another chicken bowl for a couple bucks more. Other than that I would def recommend this place.

Man this place great choice for Hawaiian food in Las Vegas! Living in Hawaii and visiting family in Vegas, what better place to eat and talk story like Aloha Kitchen. Market Street Cafe would be another place that the locals go and eat, but Aloha Kitchen & Bar is so ono!

They place closes pretty late so you can get your late night grinds on if your up past 12am.

What I got was Local plate which includes: Combination of Teriyaki Chicken, Beef and 2 Spam Musubi. It included more rice also. I think they can cut back on the rice that isn't in the Musubi and give an extra scoop of mac salad.

The teri beef and chicken was cooked awesome. It wasn't over cooked and tough. The chicken was easy to cut and so was the teriyaki beef. The teriyaki sauce catered to the masses and more of a mainland pallet but I thought it was very delish!

THe Musibi could have been wrapped a little tighter because it was falling apart when i took a bite out of it.

Pricing was on point too. nothing crazy like paying on the strip, but for the amount of food you get, and the price you pay, its a deal!

Everyone praises the adobo fried rice but I didn't try it this time. I'll most defiantly try ti next time in in town and craving some local hawaiian food.

Over all, love this place and will be visiting it more when im back in Vegas.

Went here yesterday afternoon. 2nd time in the location. Ordered the same food. Loco Moco. And it's not good like the last time I had. The gravy is good but the patty is not. It taste kinda bad,sour. While the first one, the patty taste good. And the service is not that friendly unlike last time. Maybe the food and service is better at night than afternoon.

Good food, lousy service. We used to frequent aloha, but lately the service is just so bad I can't bring myself to spend money there. The younger cashiers lack aloha and the older lady was flat out rude the last time we were there. She spent 15 minutes arguing with me that I ordered something I didn't. Thankfully I had my receipt to show her what I ordered. Too many Hawaiian food places in Vegas to put up with subpar service.
Definitely divey but whatever.  Its cheap, fast, good and open late.  No place for me to get gyu-don after 4am so this place works just fine.

Quick simple bite. Not sure what the hypes about the food isn't that great. Comparable to a crappy Chinese takeout place food wise. Ordered for 5 colleagues and myself. Everyone hated there food. Top three was moco plate, chicken katsu, and adobo. Won't be returning.

Please don't order teriyaki beef from this restaurant, especially if you are from Hawaii.  Such a shame that they use the name "Aloha" and people think they will be served thin sliced teriyaki beef similar to what is served at all plate lunch locations in Hawaii.  They chop up prolly the lowest grade of beef, tuff as rubber and pour teriyaki sauce on it.

This is one of my go-to places and one of my favorites. Food that I could never get sick of. My usual order is the student special, which is just a bowl of teriyaki chicken and Japanese sticky rice and a drink for just $6.05 (including tax)! I also love getting the $1 turon (banana egg roll). The Teriyaki Combo (teriyaki chicken, pork, and beef with rice and macaroni salad) is also delicious. The tapsilog (rice with sunny side up egg and beef) doesn't really taste like legit tapa (beef). The spam musubi is something you can easily make one at home. You can order better eggroll at an actual Filipino restaurant, but it's nice that they offer it. The Saimin Soup is kind of salty. There is also a karaoke bar adjacent to the restaurant, which I have been meaning to check out.  This place is good for breakfast, lunch, dinner, or after a night out partying!

First time at this location... I've been going to the Maryland Pkwy location near UNLV for many years. I like this one. Not cause there's a bar but It's actually not that far from the strip. Still not a short a drive as the other one but it almost seems like there are more options at this location on Decatur.

My friends & I were starving for some local food one late Saturday night. We were coming from Bellagio and it was near closing time for the other location so we made a beeline for Decatur because it's open much later. This restaurant is located in an outdoor shopping plaza. There was plenty of parking.

I ordered the lau lau and a side of spam musubi. Having come back from visiting Hawai'i a few months ago, I was really craving some authentic local grindz. Craving fulfilled... The pork lau-lau was good. It had good flavor. I just wish there was more of it than the serving had. I guess I really was hungry cause I scarfed the musubi and lau-lau in no time. Haha. My friends all liked what they ordered... I usually go for a bento box or local plate. Next time for sure.

Service was friendly just like the other location. Pay and order at the counter. You get a number and they bring you your food, drinks and utensils. I look forward to going back to this location whenever I'm in town to not only check out the other menu items but to see the bar area... I know this is where Anuhea performed when she was in town. That's awesome..

I ordered the "grilled" mahi-mahi plate and ended up receiving a mahi-mahi omelette. I politely went to the counter to clarify my order, but the employee, a young kid, claimed the mahi-mahi plate is cooked with egg. If that is the case, then the menu should clearly state that. Not grilled. I didn't want to argue simply because I was wary of having something done to my reorder, didn't want to waste food, and was already starving. On top of that, the mahi-mahi omelettes were extremely bland (along with the side of mac salad) that I needed to add a lot of Aloha soy sauce which was probably the only best thing about my meal.

It has been a minute since I last came by.  It looks like there have been some aesthetic upgrades since many last visit.  The menu is now displayed on several flat screen TV'S.  The seating is nicely furnished and the staff is friendly and welcoming as always.

Not sure if they still hold karaoke events nightly here, but, it is definitely a popular spot for some plate lunch grinds.  

As you may or may not be aware of...there is a high amount of Islanders in Las Vegas.  This translates into a high amount of Hawaiian style eateries.  In my humble opinion, Aloha Kitchen does not "wow" me much with their menu.  They are mediocre at best with their staples.  However, where Aloha Kitchen makes up for this, is with menu items that can't be found everywhere.  

For instance, just the name of adobo friend rice instantly turns you into a rubber necker doing double takes.  It's difficult to choose anything else unless you tried it for the first time.  Not bad, but not special, although, no other place serves this to my knowledge.

I hope the avid Aloha kitchen heads don't take offense to my review, but simply put, I have had better.  Ross J's don't necessarily tickle my pickle and and L&L's doesn't quite float my boat in this respect either.

Hands down...I have to roll with Big Island Flavor with a close tie by Island Style, Rice Tracks & Ohana's.  If Hawaiian Hale still existed, they would be near the top indeed.

It's all about preference, and I tend to judge a lot on particular aspects such as mac salad and so forth.  You can bet if I get the itch for the homeland grinds, AK was still be considered.

Aloha Yelp Fam!

Aloha would always have earned a 4 for me in the past. But today, we ordered our usual corned beef hash dishes. The cornee beef serving was tiny. I guess they are trying to save money on their food now...
I'm a fan of their adobo fried rice omelet.  Pretty damn good.  But i was drunk so I can only give it so many stars.  For sure coming back to it when I go back to Vegas.

I'm a big fan of Aloha Kitchen! The Decatur and Sahara location is definitely my favorite location that I go to because it's closer compared to the other locations that they have. The establishment is definitely clean, the staff is nice, and I've never had any major issues with their food.

The pricing for their meals is pretty decent. You get a lot for what you order, especially for what I* order when I come here. I usually get the Local Plate. It consists of beef and chicken teriyaki, macaroni salad, two spam musubis, and rice. I don't know what they use for their teriyaki sauce but it's definitely my favorite. And one of the main reasons why I always come back here. 

The only reason why I didn't give them five stars is because I really don't like how I have to buy the drinks separately. I wish they came in as a combo with your meal or something. And also the quality sometimes of the beef and chicken is sometimes eh.. I sometimes would have more fat than meat in the beef AND chicken. No bueno. Other than that, I love place. Definitely will keep coming back for more.

Forget the 2 hour wait at Bacchanal, what more could you ask for from Filipino/Hawaiian fusion. Unfortunately, my favorite Vegas day club had a wait time that did not fit within the time constraints of my day.
